<task>
Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example
</task>

<data>
wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")
</data>

Here is the `wrap_string` function:

<approach>
- Take a deep breath
- Think through the approach step by step
- Write the function
- Solve the task
- Check the solution
</approach>

```julia
function wrap_string(text; text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    lines = Vector{String}()
    current_line = ""
    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = ""
        end
        current_line = isempty(current_line) ? word : "$current_line $word"
    end
    push!(lines, current_line)
    return join(lines, "\n")
end

# Example usage
text = "This function will wrap words into lines"
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)
println(wrapped_text)
```

This will output:

```
This
function
will
wrap
words
into
lines
```

The `wrap_string` function first splits the input text into words using `split(text)`. It then iterates over the words, and if adding the current word to the current line would exceed the `text_width`, it adds the current line to the `lines` array and starts a new line. Finally, it joins the lines back into a single string and returns it.
